No more “where’s that file?” or “did you send the latest version?” Everything lives right with the work - attached to the task or section it belongs to. You cut the clutter of shared drives and email attachments. Team members grab what they need in one click, clients see only what you want them to, and everyone works off the same up-to-date file. It keeps projects moving without the back-and-forth.

Attach anywhere – Drop files directly into projects, sections, tasks, subtasks or even a message. Preview without download – Click images, or PDFs, to see them right in the browser. Permission controls – Set who can view, edit, or download -team, client, or read-only. Search & filter – Find any file by name, type, or uploader in seconds. Direct links – Share a secure link to a file without giving full project access.
To access File view, refer File View To upload a file, refer Upload File
Attach documents, images, or spreadsheets directly to a project, section, task, subtask, or message. Once uploaded, files stay linked to the work, ready for preview, download, or version updates.
The Files feature is available to all subscription plans. However, the total file upload limit depends on your plan: Subscription Plan File Upload Limit Free 2 GB Growth 100 GB
Only users with upload permission can upload files to the Files View.

A file can be uploaded in three different ways: Upload from Computer Users can directly upload files from their local system. Select the file from your computer and click to upload. Upload via Google Drive You can upload files stored in your Google Drive. Simply connect your Google Drive account, select the file, and it will be uploaded to 5day.io. Upload via OneDrive Upload files from OneDrive by connecting your OneDrive account. Select the file from OneDrive, and it will be uploaded to 5day.io.
To access File view, refer File View To download a file, refer Download File

The Customize option in List View lets you control exactly what fields you want to see—and in what order. You can show or hide fields, rearrange them, and even create new custom fields to fit your project needs.
Open any project (it opens in List View by default). Click on the Customize button at the top-right corner. The Column Options panel will appear, showing all available standard and custom fields.

You’ll see two types of fields in the Column Options panel: 1. Standard Fields​ These are built-in fields like: Due Date Task Type Task ID Section Start Date Progress Budget Type * Tags * Estimation * Story Point * Created By Created On Updated By Updated On Priority Assignee Status Note: Fields marked with an asterisk (*) appear only if the related Project Features are enabled. 2. Custom Fields​ Any custom fields created within the project will also appear here. You can: Toggle visibility of custom fields Drag and drop to reorder them Create new custom fields directly from this panel What You Can Do​ Toggle Visibility: Use the switch to turn a field on or off in the List View. Reorder Fields: Drag and drop fields to change their position. Pin Fields: Click the pin icon 📌 to lock a field’s position (it stays fixed when scrolling). Create Custom Fields: Click + New Custom Field at the bottom to define a new field and apply it to tasks. Saving Your Changes​ When you make any changes in the Column Options panel: A message will appear: “This view has unsaved changes.” You’ll see a Save button and a cancel (❌) icon at the top. Click Save to apply and store your selected column option for this project. Changes won’t take effect until you save. User-Specific Customization​ Customize settings are user-specific. Each user can choose which columns to show, hide, or reorder, and it will not affect how other users view the same project. The customization is saved per project—so when a user returns to the project, their preferred column layout remains intact. Notes​ Some fields like Budget Type, Tags, Estimation, Story Point, and Priority will only appear if the corresponding features are enabled in Project Settings. Custom fields, once added, can be reused across all tasks in the same project.

Filters in List View allow you to narrow down tasks based on specific conditions so you can focus on exactly what you need. Whether you're trying to view tasks assigned to a specific person or filter by status, the Filter panel helps you filter your project data efficiently. Filters are contextual, dynamic, and highly flexible. They support both standard fields (e.g., Assignee, Status, Due Date) and custom fields created for the project. Multiple filters can be combined using the AND operator, ensuring that only tasks matching all conditions appear in the List View. Filter configuration is user-specific, meaning every user can apply their own filter set without affecting anyone else.

Navigate to any Project and open it in List View Click on the Filter icon located at the top-right of the screen. The Filter Panel will open in an expanded view showing: Current applied filters (if any) “No filters applied yet” message (if none exist) The + Add button to create new filter conditions
documents.s: How to Access the Filter Panel

documents.t: When there are no filters applied: You will see a message: “No filters applied yet” A + Add button will be available to create your first filter The panel will remain empty until a filter is added You may start adding conditions immediately.
documents.s: Default State (When No Filters Are Applied)

documents.t: When you click + Add, a new filter row appears. Each filter consists of three parts:
This is the attribute you want to filter by, such as: Assignee Status Due Date Start Date Priority Tags Any Custom Field …and more. Once the field is selected, the next dropdown becomes active.
Operators depend on the selected field. Examples: Equals Not Equals Is One Of Is Not One Of On or Before On or After Before / After Is Empty / Is Not Empty (See detailed operator table below.)

This is the actual value used for filtering. Examples: Assignee → Jayesh Status → In Progress Due Date → 05–Nov–2025 Tags → SEO, Design Priority → High Values depend on the field and are populated dynamically. Adding Multiple Filters​ Click + Add to create additional filter rows. All filters use the AND condition, meaning: Only tasks that satisfy all selected filter conditions will be shown.
You can click on any dropdown (Field / Operator / Value) and change it. All validations are handled automatically — e.g., value must be selected.
Click the Delete (🗑️) icon next to a filter row. Filter will be removed immediately without confirmation.
Available only when at least one filter is applied. Click Clear Filters (bottom-right). All filters are removed instantly. The panel resets to default state.

There is no Save button for filters. Filters use auto-save: Any change made is saved automatically Clicking outside the filter panel: Closes the panel Retains all applied filters Applies the filtered view to the List View immediately Your filter preferences persist until you manually clear them.
The table below shows which operators are supported for each field to ensure accurate filtering.

Field Supported Operators Section Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Assignee Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Status Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Priority Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Task Type Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Tags Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Budget Type Equals, Is One Of Start Date On or Before, On or After, Equals, Not Equals, Before, After, Is Empty, Is Not Empty Due Date On or Before, On or After, Equals, Not Equals, Before, After, Is Empty, Is Not Empty Created On On or Before, On or After, Equals, Not Equals, Before, After Updated On On or Before, On or After, Equals, Not Equals, Before, After, Is Empty, Is Not Empty

Custom Field Type Supported Operators Dropdown Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Radio Button Equals Rating Equals, Not Equals Multiselect Dropdown Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of
When at least one filter is active: The Filter icon becomes highlighted A small dot or indicator will show that filters are in use This helps users quickly identify that the view is filtered

Filters are user-specific — each user has their own filter preferences. Filters are project-specific — the filter set applied to one project won’t affect another. Feature-based fields (e.g., Tags, Budget Type, Story Points) only appear if those features are enabled in the Project Settings. Filtering applies instantly and updates the task list in real-time.

The Group By feature in List View allows you to organize and visually segment your tasks based on a specific field. This helps you quickly understand how task is distributed—whether by Section, Assignee, Status, Priority, or any custom categorization configured in the project. Grouping is especially useful for project managers and team members who want a structured view of tasks, identify bottlenecks, or review workload distribution across team members or categories. Key highlights: User-specific: Each user can set their own grouping without affecting others. Project-specific: The selected grouping is saved only for that particular project. Single grouping at a time: Only one field can be applied for grouping. Option to remove grouping: Selecting None resets the List View to a flat, ungrouped state.

Navigate to any Project and open it in List View. At the top of the screen, click on Group By : <current-value>. A dropdown will appear showing all standard fields and supported custom fields. Select the field you want to group the tasks by. Save the view when prompted to apply the grouping.

The List View is reorganized into expandable sections, each representing the selected field’s values. Tasks automatically move into their respective groups. Any fields dependent on project features (e.g., Budget Type) appear only when those project features are enabled.
documents.s: What Happens When Grouping Is Applied

documents.t: Standard Fields​ Section Assignee Status Priority Task Type Budget Type * Tags * Note: Some standard fields appear only if their related project feature is enabled. Supported Custom Fields​ Only the following custom field types are supported for Group By: Dropdown Rating Radio Button Special Option​ None Selecting None removes all grouping and returns the List View to its default, ungrouped layout.

Whenever you change the Group By selection: A banner appears: “This view has unsaved changes.” You will see a Save button and a Cancel (❌) icon. Click Save to apply the grouping. If you navigate away without saving, the changes will not persist. Once saved, the grouping is stored for: That project That specific user This ensures every user can have their own personalized List View experience.

The List View provides a clean, table-style layout of all tasks within a project. It is ideal for teams that prefer a structured, spreadsheet-like interface for reviewing, organizing, and managing work. With List View, you can quickly view task details, reorder fields, apply filters, and configure personalized views tailored to your workflow.

View Tasks​ All tasks (and subtasks, based on configuration) are displayed in a clear, structured list for quick access and navigation. Add Tasks​ Use the Add Task button to create tasks directly from the List View without switching screens. Search Tasks​ Search by task name, task ID, task type, status, priority, assignee, or supported custom field values to instantly locate the right task. Filter Tasks​ Narrow down your task list using filters. You can filter by fields such as Section, Status, Assignee, Priority, Task Type, Dates, Tags, Budget Type, and supported Custom Fields. Sort Tasks​ Sort tasks by standard fields or custom fields to bring the most important tasks to the top of the list. Group By​ Organize tasks into meaningful groups — such as by Section, Assignee, Status, Priority, Task Type, Tags, or supported Custom Fields. Customize View​ Choose which columns to show or hide, drag and reorder fields, pin important fields, or create new custom fields — all through the Customize panel. Actions in List View You can personalize and control the appearance and behavior of List View using the three-dot menu (⋮) at the top-right corner. These view-level actions include: Show completed tasks Show completed subtasks Show completed sections Show subtask as a separate task Save View Set as Default View Reset to Default View Each action helps you control visibility, structure, and default behavior of the List View in a project. All configurations are user-specific and project-specific.
documents.s: What You Can Do in List View

documents.t: List View is available on all subscription plans of 5day.io.
The tasks you see and the actions available in List View depend on your assigned role and permission set. For complete details, refer to the dedicated guide: Roles and Permissions for Tasks

List View provides additional controls that help you fine-tune how tasks, subtasks, and sections are displayed. These settings allow you to show or hide completed tasks, manage how subtasks appear, and define or reset your default view for the project. These configurations are: User-specific (every user can maintain their own preferences) Project-specific (changes apply only to the project in which they are made) This menu ensures that each user can tailor the List View to match their working and reviewing style.
Navigate to any Project → List View. At the top-right corner, click the three-dot menu (⋯). A menu will open listing all available view-related options.
documents.s: How to Access the Additional Features

documents.t: Below are detailed explanations of every option available in the three-dot menu. 1. Show Completed Tasks​ This option controls the visibility of tasks that are marked as Done (i.e., tasks whose status belongs to the "Done" stage). How it works:​ Enabled (✓) → Completed tasks are visible. Disabled → Completed tasks are hidden from the List View. Notes:​ This is a show/hide control only. No task data is deleted. Useful for decluttering the view when working with large ongoing projects. 2. Show Completed Subtasks​ Functions identically to Show Completed Tasks, but specifically for subtasks. Behavior:​ Enabled (✓) → Completed subtasks appear under their parent tasks (or separately, if “Show subtask as a separate task” is active). Disabled → All subtasks with status in Done stage are hidden. 3. Show Completed Sections​ Sections also have statuses (New, In Progress, Done). Behavior:​ If this option is disabled, all sections marked Done will be hidden from the List View. If enabled (✓), completed sections are shown normally. 4. Save View​ Use Save View to save all the visual configurations currently applied, such as: Filters Sort selections Group By configuration Column customizations (Customize → visibility/reorder) 5. Set as Default View​ This option allows the user to set the current List View state as their default view for the project. Behavior:​ Once set, every time the user opens this project, the chosen view will be automatically loaded. The default view may include: Selected columns Group By field Sort field Filters Any other view-level configurations applied by the user (e.g., Show completed tasks, Show subtasks as separate tasks, etc.) 6. Reset to Default View​ This option restores the system’s original List View configuration. What it resets:​ All filters Sort order Group By selection Any other view-level configurations applied by the user (e.g., Show completed tasks, Show subtasks as separate tasks, etc.) 7. Show Subtask as a Separate Task​ This option determines how subtasks appear in the List View. Behavior:​ Enabled (✓): Subtasks appear directly inside their corresponding sections (if the subtask’s section is different from the parent task). The user can treat them like standalone tasks in the list. Disabled: Subtasks appear only inside their parent task, visible when expanding the parent row. Notes:​ This is especially helpful for teams using multiple sections or workflows where subtasks move independently.

The Sort option in List View helps you organize how tasks are displayed by ordering them based on a specific field—such as Due Date, Priority, Estimation, or even Custom Fields. When sections are used in a project, sorting is applied within each section, so tasks under each section will be ordered based on your selected sort field. This makes it easier to view tasks in a way that fits your workflow, such as viewing all tasks by earliest due date or status.

Open any Project in List View. Click the Sort button located at the top-right of the screen. Select the field you want to sort by. Click again on the same field to toggle between ascending and descending order. Tasks will automatically reorder based on the selected field and direction.

1. Standard Fields​ You can apply sort on the following built-in fields: Name Priority Start Date Due Date Estimation * Story Point * Created On Updated On Logged Time Note: Fields marked with * appear only if the related Project Features are enabled in Project Settings. 2. Custom Fields​ Sort is supported for the following Custom Field types: Text Box Dropdown Rating Date Time Date & Time Email Radio Button User-Specific Sorting​ Sorting is user-specific. Each user can apply their own sort order, and it won’t impact how others view the project. The sort preference is saved per project—so when a user returns to the project later, their sort order is preserved.

When you make any changes in the Sort panel: A banner will appear: “This view has unsaved changes.” You’ll see a Save button and a Cancel (❌) icon. Click Save to apply and store your selected sort order for this project. 📝 Notes​ Sorting is applied section-wise. If your project uses sections, the tasks within each section will be sorted independently. You can only apply one sort criteria at a time (single-field sort).

Filters in Timeline View allow you to narrow down tasks and subtasks based on specific conditions so you can focus on exactly what you need. Whether you want to view tasks assigned to a specific person or filter by status or dates, the Filter panel helps you refine your timeline efficiently. Filters are dynamic and flexible. They support both standard fields (such as Assignee, Status, Priority, Start Date, Due Date) and any custom fields created for the project. You can add multiple filter conditions, and all filters are combined using the AND operator—meaning only the tasks that satisfy all selected conditions appear in the Timeline View. Filtered tasks appear on the timeline only if their start date or due date falls within the visible date range.

Navigate to any Project and open it in Timeline View Click on the Filter icon located at the top-right of the screen. The Filter Panel will open in an expanded view showing: Current applied filters (if any) “No filters applied yet” message (if none exist) The + Add button to create new filter conditions
documents.s: How to Access the Filter Panel

documents.t: When there are no filters applied: You will see a message: “No filters applied yet” A + Add button will be available to create your first filter The panel will remain empty until a filter is added You may start adding conditions immediately.
documents.s: Default State (When No Filters Are Applied)

documents.t: When you click + Add, a new filter row appears. Each filter consists of three parts: 1. Field Selector (Where)​ This is the attribute you want to filter by, such as: Assignee Status Due Date Start Date Priority Tags Any Custom Field …and more. Once the field is selected, the next dropdown becomes active. 2. Operator​ Operators depend on the selected field. Examples: Equals Not Equals Is One Of Is Not One Of On or Before On or After Before / After Is Empty / Is Not Empty (See detailed operator table below.) 3. Value​ This is the actual value used for filtering. Examples: Assignee → Jayesh Status → In Progress Due Date → 05–Nov–2025 Tags → SEO, Design Priority → High Values depend on the field and are populated dynamically. Adding Multiple Filters​ Click + Add to create additional filter rows. All filters use the AND condition, meaning: Only tasks that satisfy all selected filter conditions will be shown.
You can click on any dropdown (Field / Operator / Value) and change it. All validations are handled automatically — e.g., value must be selected.
Click the Delete (🗑️) icon next to a filter row. Filter will be removed immediately without confirmation.
Available only when at least one filter is applied. Click Clear Filters (bottom-right). All filters are removed instantly. The panel resets to default state.

There is no Save button for filters. Filters use auto-save: Any change made is saved automatically Clicking outside the filter panel: Closes the panel Retains all applied filters Applies the filtered view to the Timeline View immediately Your filter preferences persist until you manually clear them.

The table below shows which operators are supported for each field to ensure accurate filtering. Standard Fields​ Field Supported Operators Section Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Assignee Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Status Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Priority Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Task Type Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Tags Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Budget Type Equals, Is One Of Start Date On or Before, On or After, Equals, Not Equals, Before, After, Is Empty, Is Not Empty Due Date On or Before, On or After, Equals, Not Equals, Before, After, Is Empty, Is Not Empty Created On On or Before, On or After, Equals, Not Equals, Before, After Updated On On or Before, On or After, Equals, Not Equals, Before, After, Is Empty, Is Not Empty Custom Fields​ Custom Field Type Supported Operators Dropdown Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Radio Button Equals Rating Equals, Not Equals Multiselect Dropdown Equals, Not Equals, Is One Of, Is Not One Of Filter Indicators​ When at least one filter is active: The Filter icon becomes highlighted A small dot or indicator will show that filters are in use This helps users quickly identify that the view is filtered Important Notes​ Filters are user-specific — each user has their own filter preferences. Filters are project-specific — the filter set applied to one project won’t affect another. Feature-based fields (e.g., Tags, Budget Type, Story Points) only appear if those features are enabled in the Project Settings. Filtering applies instantly and updates the timeline in real-time.

The Group By feature in Timeline View allows you to organize and visually segment your tasks. This helps you understand how work is distributed—whether by Section, Assignee, Status, Priority, or any supported custom field—directly on the timeline. Grouping makes it easier to review workload distribution, identify scheduling gaps, and analyze how tasks are allocated across different categories. Key highlights: User-specific: Each user can set their own grouping without affecting others. Project-specific: The selected grouping is saved only for that project. Single grouping: Only one Group By field can be applied at a time. Option to reset: Selecting None returns the Timeline View to an ungrouped layout.

Navigate to any Project and open it in Timeline View. At the top toolbar, click Group By : <current-value>. A dropdown will appear showing all supported fields. Select the field you want to group by. Save the view when prompted.

The Timeline View is reorganized into groups displayed in the left panel. Each group represents one value of the selected Group By field (e.g., each Assignee, each Status). Each group has: Expand/Collapse icon Group name Tasks that match the group appear as task bars in the timeline area. Groups remain visible even if no tasks match the selected date range or filters. These groups show the text: “No tasks available.” Supported Fields for Grouping​ Standard Fields​ Section Assignee Status Priority Task Type Budget Type* Tags* *Shown only when the corresponding project feature is enabled. Custom Fields​ Only the following custom field types support grouping: Dropdown Rating Radio Button Special Option​ None Selecting None removes grouping and returns the Timeline View to an ungrouped state. Saving Your Changes​ Whenever you change the Group By selection: A banner appears: “This view has unsaved changes.” You will see a Save button and a Cancel (✖) icon. Click Save to apply and store the grouping. Saved grouping is specific to: That project That user This ensures every user gets a personalized Timeline View.
documents.s: What Happens When Grouping Is Applied

documents.t: Group By works together with Filters. Groups still appear even if no tasks match the filter.

Timeline View shows all project tasks and subtasks on a calendar-based timeline. Each task appears as a bar between its start date and due date. This helps you: Track when the task starts and ends. See overlaps and gaps between tasks. Understand how work is distributed across weeks and months. By default, Timeline opens in a 3-week view, so you can see recent past, today, and upcoming work together. Note: The exact number of days visible depends on your screen resolution and zoom level.
Timeline View is available for all plans where: The Timeline view is enabled for that project in Project Settings → Views.

Timeline View follows the same task-level roles and permissions defined in 5day.io. What a user can view and what they can modify in Timeline View depends entirely on their assigned Task Roles and Permissions. Users can only see the tasks and subtasks they have permission to view. Actions such as dragging tasks, resizing dates, or editing details depend on their edit permissions. For complete details on task visibility and allowed actions, refer to the Task Roles & Permissions documentation: **https://github.com/5dayGit/5day_Docusaurus/blob/main/docs/user-guide/5day.io Structure/Task/Roles and Permission of Task.md**
Open the project. Click the three-dot menu (⋮) next to the project name. Select Project Settings. Go to the Views section. Turn on the Timeline toggle. Save and return to the project.
Open the project where you want to view the timeline. In the project, click Timeline in the view. The project opens in Timeline View with a default 3-week range.

Timeline View is divided into three main areas: Top Toolbar Today selector Selector: Week / Month Previous / Next navigation arrows Filter Group By (defaults to Section) Left Panel (Groups) Shows groups based on the selected Group By field (for example, Section, Assignee). Each group has: Expand / collapse icon Group name If a group has no tasks, it shows “No tasks available.” Timeline Area Horizontal axis shows dates. Vertical axis shows groups and their tasks. Each task or subtask is displayed as a coloured bar with: Task type icon Task name (trimmed if long) Subtask indication icon along with Subtask count Assignee avatar A horizontal scrollbar at the bottom lets you move left and right across the timeline.

Previous / Next​ Previous (‹): moves to the previous range. Week View → previous week. Month View → previous month. Next (›): moves to the next week or next month. The timeline updates immediately with tasks for the new date range. Horizontal Scroll​ Use the scrollbar at the bottom or drag/scroll with mouse/trackpad to move left or right. The date header and task bars move together so you always see correct alignment of dates and tasks.

For each task, Timeline shows a bar from its start date to its due date. You can: Hover to see task complete task/subtask title. Click to open the full Task/Subtask Details panel on the right. Subtask Indicator and Expand / Collapse​ If a task has subtasks, Timeline shows a subtask indicator on the task bar. Clicking the indicator expands the parent task to show its subtasks. Subtasks appear as separate bars under the parent, each with its own start and due dates. The same drag and resize interactions apply to subtasks, subject to permissions. You can collapse the parent again to hide subtasks and keep the view compact. Subtasks are always accessed through their parent task via the subtask indicator.
Timeline allows direct date editing by drag-and-drop.

Hover over a task or subtask bar until the drag cursor appears. Click and hold the bar. Drag it left or right to the new date range. Release to drop. Both start and due dates move together, keeping the same duration. Changes are saved automatically and reflected in other views.
documents.s: Move Task or Subtask to New Dates

documents.t: Hover over the left or right edge of the bar. When the resize handle appears: Drag the left edge to change the start date. Drag the right edge to change the due date. Release to save the new duration. Resizing works for both tasks and subtasks, based on your edit permissions.

If you drag a task towards the left or right edge of the visible timeline: The timeline will auto-scroll in that direction. This allows you to move tasks to dates that are currently outside the viewport without stopping the drag operation. Scrolling stops as soon as you move the cursor away from the edge or drop the bar. Note: Timeline currently works on dates, not time-of-day. Tasks are treated as full-day events in this view.

Timeline View supports multiple date-based views that help you understand tasks across different date ranges. You can switch between Week and Month views depending on how much detail you want to see, and use the Today option to instantly return to the current date. Each view adjusts the layout of tasks and subtasks on the timeline to give you a clear picture of scheduled work and upcoming deadlines. Week View​ Shows 7 days at a time. Each column is one calendar day. Multi-day tasks appear as continuous bars across multiple columns. Best suited for weekly planning and short-term execution. Month View​ Shows the full month (depending on calendar). The view is more compact, and tasks appear as bars or chips at their respective dates. Best suited for long-term planning, milestones, and quarterly overviews. Today​ Centers the timeline on today’s date and highlights it with a vertical line. Useful when you have navigated far into the past or future dates.

Timeline View Zoom levels control how much of the timeline you can see at once. Using the + and – icons, you can zoom in to focus on a smaller date range or zoom out to see a broader period such as a full month or quarter. Zooming changes: The number of days or months visible on screen The width of each date column The density of task bars on the timeline This helps you switch easily between detailed scheduling and high-level planning. For example, zooming in is useful when adjusting specific task dates, while zooming out helps understand overall project timelines and milestones.

Use the + – icons in the bottom-right corner to adjust zoom. Zoom changes how much date is visible and the width of each date column: Level 1 – Highest zoom-in, approx. 1 week visible. Level 2 (Default) – About 3 weeks visible. Level 3 – 1 month visible. Level 4 – 1 quarter (3 months) visible. Level 5 – 2 quarters (6 months) visible (for example, Q3 and Q4).

The Timesheet View in 5day.io allows users to manage, record, and visualize time logged across all their projects in one place. It provides a centralized space for individuals and teams to track working hours, analyze utilization, and ensure accurate time reporting for billable and non-billable work. Timesheet View offers two main sections — Timesheet and Time Approval — that appear side by side at the top of the screen. Timesheet is where users can add, edit, and view their logged hours in multiple time-based layouts such as Day, Week, Month, and List. Time Approval is available only if the project has timesheet approval enabled. Here, authorized users can review and approve submitted timesheets for their team members. Each view (Day, Week, Month, and List) presents logged time in a different format to suit different needs. Users can switch between views with a single click, making it easy to see daily breakdowns, weekly summaries, or monthly overviews of time logged across tasks and projects. Alongside these views, users can search or filter entries based on task name, task ID, member, status, or billable type. This helps refine data visibility and focus on specific details, such as pending approvals or billable time entries.

The Timesheet View in 5day.io is designed to give users complete control and flexibility when tracking their working hours. It includes essential tools to log, review, and analyze time entries efficiently, ensuring teams stay aligned and accountable.
Users can log hours using two simple options: Add Time: Used to record a single time entry for a specific day. Add Bulk Time: Allows entering time entries for multiple days in one go.
Users can switch between four distinct views to manage and analyze logged time:

Day View: Displays a detailed, hour-by-hour breakdown of all entries for a single day. Week View: Provides a summary of time logged for each day of the week. Month View: Shows total time logged across the entire month. List View: Presents a detailed table with all logged hours for members within the project. Each view adapts to different use cases — from daily time tracking to long-term utilization review.

The Calendar Widget helps users navigate across days, weeks, or months depending on the selected view: In Day View, users can select a specific date. In Week View, users can select a specific week. In Month View, users can select a specific month. In List View, users can select a week to see all entries within that duration. In Time Approval, the calendar defaults to the current week for easy review of team submissions.
In Showing For, users can view their own timesheet or select other members if they have permission. The option to view All Members is available only in List View.
Use the search bar in any view to quickly locate entries by Task ID, Task Name, or People. This helps users find relevant time logs without scrolling through multiple records.

Apply filters to focus on specific types of time entries: Status: All, To Submit, Pending Approval, Approved, or Rejected. Billable Type: Billable or Non-Billable. Filtering helps narrow results for better review and reporting accuracy.

Users can instantly view important time statistics through three key metrics: Total Logged: Displays total logged hours versus total allocated capacity (for example, 5h/9h). Pending to Log: Shows the remaining hours that are yet to be logged. Utilization: Shows the percentage of hours logged against the total allocated capacity. These insights help users and managers evaluate productivity and ensure balanced workloads.
If time approval is enabled, the Time Approval tab allows managers or authorized users to review and approve timesheets. Key features include:

Members List: Displays all members who have logged time in the selected week. Calendar Widget: Enables week selection for reviewing submissions. Showing For: View all members or filter by a single member. Filter: Filter by Billable or Non-Billable entries. Search: Quickly locate entries or members for review by searching using Task ID, Task Name, or People. Approve / Reject: Approve valid entries or reject those needing corrections. This ensures time data is validated before being finalized in reports.

Views in 5day.io help you organize and visualize your project tasks in the way that works best for you and your team. Whether you're reviewing a long list of tasks or managing work through visual stages, 5day.io supports multiple powerful ways to interact with your project: List View – See all tasks in a structured list format. Board View – View tasks as cards and drag them across stages (like “New,” “In Progress,” and “Done”). Timesheet View – Track time entries across days, weeks, or months. Dashboard – Analyze work through prebuilt reports and widgets. Files View – Store, upload, and manage project files. Discussion View – Start and reply to conversations around the project. Activity Stream – View a real-time feed of all project changes. These views are project-specific and tightly integrated with your workflows. Users with project settings access can customize views to suit their needs.
